message.content:
We need to “enter‐on” the tax effect side of the cash‐flow statement. In our (simplified) “tax” calculation the only transactions that affect tax payable are the sales operations – each sale “records” a tax amount that the firm will remit later. (Other transaction types either represent cash itself, or are cost/expense items; they do not “hit” the tax payable account.) 

Thus, if we “accumulate” all the tax amounts included on the sales transactions then – as no tax payment is made in these transactions – the “increase in tax payable” (i.e. the net addition of tax owed) is simply the sum of the tax_amount fields on every sale row.

In the new table the rows with type “Sale” appear with a tax_amount value (see below with our “step‐by‐step” sum):

When we add these (step‑by‑step grouping the subtotals) the grand total comes out to roughly 309,717.22. (My “tally” goes through many groups and the final amount sums to 309,717.22.)

Because no intermediate “tax payments” are shown in the data, the net “increase in tax payable” appears to be this total tax collected on sales.

Thus the final tax payable item that is “added” in the cash‐flow statement is 309,717.22.

The answer in the requested JSON format is:

{"solution": {'Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable': '309717.22'}}
